docs.title: PowerShell module for Frigate
docs.text:
This unofficial Frigate PowerShell module provides convenient cmdlets for working with the Frigate REST API.

Frigate is an open-source MIT-licensed network video recorder application you can run anywhere. It's a popular surveillance tool with homelabbers, integrates nicely with Home Assistant, and uses locally running AI models for object detection.

Learn more at https://frigate.video/

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• PowerShell 7+ (recommended) or Windows PowerShell (5.1) with TLS 1.2 enabled
  • Network access and credentials to a Frigate server.

docs.title: Install
docs.text: Install-Module joshooaj.frigate -scope CurrentUser

docs.title: Login
docs.text:
$cred = Get-Credential -Message 'Frigate credentials'
New-FrigateSession -Uri 'https://frigate.example.local' -Credential $cred

docs.title: Common tasks
docs.text:
• View configuration: Get-FrigateConfig
  • List recent events: Get-FrigateEvent -After (Get-Date).AddDays(-1)
  • View users: Get-FrigateUsers
  • Create users: New-FrigateUser -Credential (Get-Credential) -Role admin

docs.title: Notes for users
docs.text: • Be cautious when copying command output — configuration and event payloads can include sensitive data including hostnames, IP addresses, and credentials. Redact credentials or identifiable imagery before sharing.

docs.title: Repository layout
docs.text:
• joshooaj.frigate/ — module source files.
  • Public/ — exported cmdlets (one command per .ps1). Add new public commands here.
  • Private/ — internal functions shared by commands.
  • joshooaj.frigate.psm1 — module entrypoint. At runtime this file dot-sources every script in Public/ and Private/ and exports public functions.
  • docs/en-US/ — generated help pages (platyPS-style). These are packaged into the built module under en-US/.
  • tests/ — Pester tests that run against the built module in Output/....
  • psakeFile.ps1,build.ps1 — build and test entrypoints.

docs.title: Build and test (local)
docs.text:
The project uses psake for the build process, with PowerShell module build tasks from the PowerShellBuild module. From a PowerShell prompt in the root of the repo:

# (run once) ensure build tools and dependencies are available
.\build.ps1 -Bootstrap

# Build the module without testing
.\build.ps1 -Task Build

# Build the module and run the tests (the default task is Test)
.\build.ps1

# Same as above
.\build.ps1 -Task Test

docs.title: Notes about the build
docs.text:
• The build runs dotnet tool restore and uses nbgv (dotnet global tool) to determine ModuleVersion. Ensure the dotnet CLI is installed as it is required for git-height versioning.
  • The build outputs a module under Output/joshooaj.frigate/<version>/ which contains the .psm1, .psd1, and the localized help in en-US/.
  • Tests in tests/ expect environment variables BHProjectName, BHBuildOutput, and BHProjectPath which are set by the build process; prefer running tests via build.ps1 -Task Test.

docs.title: Help and documentation
docs.text:
Command help is generated from two places:

  • Comment-based help inside Public/*.ps1 (minimal guidance users see with Get-Help).
  • Rich topic files under docs/en-US/ — generated/edited with platyPS and packaged into the module during the build.

The build process will use platyps to generate or update the markdown documentation. You can then fill out the markdown documentation. Try not to use comment-based help here as, for now, I prefer the markdown files to be the source of truth.

docs.title: How to add a new command
docs.text:
1. Add a new .ps1 file to joshooaj.frigate/Public/. Keep public cmdlet functions small and focused.
  2. Use Private/ for shared helper functions.
  3. Run ./build.ps1 -Task Test locally to build, and run tests.
  4. Write, or update the corresponding docs in docs/en-US as needed.

docs.title: Tests and quality
docs.text:
• Tests live in tests/ and use Pester. They import the built module from Output/... so that tests exercise the packaged module as CI will.
  • tests/Help.tests.ps1 validates that each exported command has non-generated help content and at least one example.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
• Fork the repository and create a branch for your change.
  • Add tests that demonstrate the bug or new behavior when possible.
  • Run ./build.ps1 -Task Test locally and ensure tests pass before opening a PR.

docs.title: Security & privacy
docs.text: • The module forwards credentials and API requests to the Frigate server; never commit secrets or credentials to the repository. Use PSCredential or secure variables when scripting.

docs.title: Questions or feedback
docs.text: • Open an issue or PR on the repository describing your request, including reproduction steps and the output of the failing command where relevant.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Closes an active session with a Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Close-FrigateSession [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
Closes (logs out) a previously opened connection to a Frigate server. Use this command when you are finished working with a Frigate instance and want to end the authenticated session.

You can run the command without arguments to close the last session created during this PowerShell session, or provide a session object if you have one saved from New-FrigateSession.

On success the session is terminated on the remote server.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Close-FrigateSession

Close the most recently created session.

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
$session = New-FrigateSession -Uri 'https://frigate.example.local' -Credential (Get-Credential)
$session | Close-FrigateSession

This closes a specific session object created earlier and ends the authenticated session on the Frigate server.

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession representing an open connection to a Frigate server. If you don't provide a session, the command will attempt to close the last session used in this PowerShell session.

Accepts pipeline input by value.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: RELATED LINKS
docs.text: New-FrigateSession

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Retrieves the current configuration from a Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-FrigateConfig [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
Returns the active Frigate server configuration as provided by the server's API. Use this command when you need to inspect server settings for troubleshooting, auditing, or backup purposes.

The command returns the server configuration as a PowerShell object (converted from JSON). Typical information includes Frigate version, authentication settings, database location, MQTT settings, camera definitions, recording and snapshot retention, detector/model settings, and other operational flags. The exact structure can vary by Frigate version.

Run the command without arguments to query the last session created in this PowerShell session, or pass a session object obtained from New-FrigateSession.

Be cautious: the configuration may contain sensitive values (for example hostnames, MQTT credentials, or other integration settings). Handle output accordingly.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Get-FrigateConfig | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 10

Display the configuration in the console (pretty-printed JSON).

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
Get-FrigateConfig | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 10 | Out-File -FilePath .\frigate-config.json -Encoding utf8

Save the configuration to a file for inspection or backup.

docs.title: Example 3
docs.text:
$session = New-FrigateSession -Uri 'https://frigate.example.local' -Credential (Get-Credential)
$session | Get-FrigateConfig

Get the configuration using a specific session object.

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Accepts pipeline input by property name or by value. Use New-FrigateSession to create a session object.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: System.Object
docs.text:
Returns a PowerShell object (typically a PSCustomObject) that mirrors the JSON configuration returned by the Frigate API.

Common top-level sections you will see:

  • version - Frigate version string.
  • auth - authentication settings (enabled, cookie name, session length).
  • database.path - location of the Frigate SQLite database.
  • mqtt - MQTT integration settings (enabled, host, port, topic prefix).
  • cameras - per-camera configuration blocks (inputs, ffmpeg, detect, record, snapshots, etc.).
  • detectors / model - object detection and model settings.
  • record / snapshots - recording and snapshot retention settings.
  • lpr, face_recognition - license-plate and face recognition settings if enabled.

Note: The payload can be large for systems with many cameras; use filtering or save to file when necessary.

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text:
If the command returns an error about the session being missing or invalid, create a session with New-FrigateSession and try again.

For large outputs, use ConvertTo-Json -Depth 10 or Out-File to capture the full structure. Avoid pasting full configurations into public channels - redact any credentials or sensitive endpoints first.

docs.title: RELATED LINKS
docs.text: New-FrigateSession

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Retrieves recent events (detections, alerts) from a Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-FrigateEvent [[-Camera] <String>] [[-Label] <String>] [[-After] <DateTime>] [[-Before] <DateTime>]
 [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
Queries the Frigate API for recorded events (for example, detected people, vehicles, or other tracked objects). Use optional filters to limit results by camera, label (object type), or time range.

Each returned event is a PowerShell object that mirrors the server's event record and includes two convenience properties, StartTime and EndTime, which are the event timestamps converted to your local time zone.

Common event fields you will see include:

  • id - unique event identifier
  • camera - camera name (example: frontdoor)
  • label - detected object label (example: person)
  • start_time, end_time - epoch timestamps returned by the server
  • has_clip, has_snapshot - booleans indicating stored media availability
  • data - additional event details (box, score, attributes, etc.)

The -After and -Before parameters accept PowerShell DateTime values; the cmdlet converts them into the format expected by the Frigate API.

Be careful when sharing event output - records may reference camera names, snapshots, or other operational details. Redact sensitive information (hostnames, credentials, or identifiable imagery) before sharing externally.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Get-FrigateEvent -After (Get-Date).AddDays(-1) | Format-Table StartTime, EndTime, camera, label, has_clip

Get recent events from the last 24 hours and list basic columns.

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
Get-FrigateEvent -Camera frontdoor -After (Get-Date).AddHours(-6)

Show events for a single camera named frontdoor.

docs.title: Example 3
docs.text:
Get-FrigateEvent -Label person -After (Get-Date).AddDays(-7) | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 5 | Out-File .\person-events.json -Encoding utf8

Retrieve only person events and save them to a file for later.

docs.title: Example 4
docs.text:
$session = New-FrigateSession -Uri 'https://frigate.example.local' -Credential (Get-Credential)
$session | Get-FrigateEvent -After (Get-Date).AddHours(-1)

Query using an explicit session object created earlier.

docs.title: -After
docs.text:
Filter results to events that occurred after the provided datetime.

Type: DateTime
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Before
docs.text:
Filter results to events that occurred before the provided datetime.

Type: DateTime
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 3
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Camera
docs.text:
Filter results to a specific camera by name (string). Example: frontdoor.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Label
docs.text:
Filter results to a specific detection label (for example person, car). The value is case-insensitive.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Accepts pipeline input by value or by property name.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 4
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: System.Object
docs.text: Each object represents a single Frigate event. The returned object includes the server fields plus StartTime and EndTime (converted to local time) for easy display.

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text:
If the command reports the session is missing or invalid, run New-FrigateSession to create a session and try again.

Events may reference stored clips or snapshots - has_clip and has_snapshot indicate whether media is available on the server for that event.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Retrieves profile information from the Frigate server for the authenticated session.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-FrigateProfile [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Returns profile details for the current authenticated user (as reported by the Frigate API). Typical information includes username and role.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Get-FrigateProfile | Format-Table username, role

Display the current profile information in a compact table.

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
$session = New-FrigateSession -BaseUri 'https://frigate.example.local' -ApiKey $env:FRIGATE_API_KEY
$session | Get-FrigateProfile

This returns profile data from the specified Frigate server.

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text:
This command queries the Frigate API api/profile endpoint and requires a valid authenticated session. If you receive an authentication error, run New-FrigateSession and try again.

Profiles may reveal user roles and accounts configured on the Frigate server - treat this data as sensitive.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Retrieve reviewable events from the Frigate server (for manual review workflows).

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-FrigateReview [[-Camera] <String[]>] [[-Label] <String[]>] [[-After] <DateTime>] [[-Before] <DateTime>]
 [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
Queries the Frigate review endpoint and returns events that require or have been marked for review. Use filters to limit results by camera(s), label(s), and time range.

Each returned object includes the usual event fields and convenience StartTime/EndTime properties converted to your local time.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Get-FrigateReview -After (Get-Date).AddDays(-1) | Select-Object StartTime, EndTime, camera

Lists review events from the last 24 hours with key columns for quick inspection.

docs.title: -After
docs.text:
Return events that started after the specified DateTime value.

Type: DateTime
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Before
docs.text:
Return events that started before the specified DateTime value.

Type: DateTime
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 3
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Camera
docs.text:
Array of camera names to include (for example frontdoor). Pass multiple values to filter several cameras.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Label
docs.text:
Array of labels (for example person, car) to filter returned review items. Case-insensitive.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 4
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: List user accounts configured on the Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-FrigateUsers [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Returns the list of user accounts and their roles from the Frigate server. Use this command to audit accounts or verify user roles.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Get-FrigateUsers

Displays all configured users and their roles.

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Send a low-level API request to a Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Invoke-FrigateApi [[-Session] <Object>] [-Path] <String> [[-Method] <String>] [[-Body] <IDictionary>]
 [[-Query] <IDictionary>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
Perform an arbitrary HTTP request against the Frigate API. This cmdlet is useful for administrators who need to call endpoints not supported by the module yet.

Provide -Path for the API endpoint and optionally -Method (default Get), a -Query dictionary for query parameters, or a -Body dictionary for JSON payloads.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Invoke-FrigateApi -Path 'api/stats'

Requests server performance stats from the Frigate instance.

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
Invoke-FrigateApi -Path 'api/events' -Query @{ camera = 'frontdoor'; after = ([datetimeoffset]::UtcNow.AddHours(-1).ToUnixTimeMilliseconds() / 1000) }

Queries recent events from the frontdoor camera in the last hour.

docs.title: Example 3
docs.text:
Invoke-FrigateApi -Path 'api/users' -Method Post -Body @{ username = 'newuser'; password = 'secret' }

Creates a new user via the API. Avoid passing plaintext secrets in shared scripts; prefer using secure credential helpers.

docs.title: -Body
docs.text:
A dictionary (key/value) that will be JSON-encoded and sent as the request body. Use this for POST or PUT requests.

Type: IDictionary
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 3
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Method
docs.text:
The HTTP method to use for the request (for example Get, Post, Put, Delete). Defaults to Get.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Path
docs.text:
The API path to call (for example api/events, api/users). Do not include a leading slash; the module will normalize the path.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Query
docs.text:
A dictionary of query parameters to append to the request URL. Keys and values will be URL-encoded.

Type: IDictionary
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 4
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Create an authenticated session to a Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: New-FrigateSession [-Uri] <Uri> [-Credential] <PSCredential> [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Authenticates to a Frigate server using the supplied URI and credentials, and returns a session object that you can use with other cmdlets in this module. The most recent session object is cached and used by default when the session parameter is not supplied.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
$cred = Get-Credential -Message 'Frigate credentials'
New-FrigateSession -Uri 'https://frigate.example.local' -Credential $cred

Creates an authenticated session to the specified Frigate server and stores it for subsequent commands.

docs.title: -Credential
docs.text:
A PSCredential containing the username and password used to authenticate to the Frigate server. Use Get-Credential to provide this interactively.

Type: PSCredential
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Uri
docs.text:
The base URI of the Frigate server (for example https://frigate.example.local). This must be a valid URI.

Type: Uri
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Create a new user account on a Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: New-FrigateUser [-Credential] <PSCredential> [[-Role] <String>] [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Creates a new user on the Frigate server using the supplied credentials and role. Provide a PSCredential object (for username and password) and optionally specify -Role (default is viewer).

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
$cred = Get-Credential -Message 'Enter new user credentials'
New-FrigateUser -Credential $cred -Role viewer

Creates a new Frigate user with the supplied credentials and assigns the viewer role.

docs.title: -Credential
docs.text:
A PSCredential object containing the username and password for the new account. Use Get-Credential to create this object interactively.

Type: PSCredential
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Role
docs.text:
The role to assign to the new user. Valid values are admin or viewer. Defaults to viewer.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:
Accepted values: admin, viewer

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Remove a user account from the Frigate server.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Remove-FrigateUser [-Username] <String> [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Deletes the specified user account from the Frigate server. This operation is permanent - removed users will no longer be able to authenticate.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Remove-FrigateUser -Username bob

Removes the user bob from the Frigate server.

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Username
docs.text:
The username of the account to remove. This value is required.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Restart a Frigate server instance.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Restart-Frigate [[-Session] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Requests a restart of the Frigate server. This triggers the server's restart endpoint and will briefly interrupt recording, streaming, and API availability.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
Restart-Frigate

Requests the remote Frigate server to restart. Expect a short service outage while the server restarts.

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession representing an authenticated connection to the Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Update an existing Frigate user's password and/or role.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Set-FrigateUser [[-Session] <Object>] [-Username] <String> [[-Password] <SecureString>] [[-Role] <String>]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Modify a user's account on a Frigate server. You can update the user's password and/or change their role (for example admin or viewer). The cmdlet requires the target -Username and accepts a secure password and role when you need to change them.

docs.title: Example 1
docs.text:
$pass = Read-Host -AsSecureString -Prompt 'New password for alice'
Set-FrigateUser -Username alice -Password $pass

Updates the password for the user alice. The secure string prevents the password from appearing in plain text.

docs.title: -Password
docs.text:
The new password for the user as a SecureString. Use Read-Host -AsSecureString to prompt for a password without echoing it.

Type: SecureString
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Role
docs.text:
The role to assign to the user. Valid values are admin or viewer. When provided, the user's role will be updated.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:
Accepted values: admin, viewer

Required: False
Position: 3
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Session
docs.text:
A session object created by New-FrigateSession that represents an authenticated connection to a Frigate server. If omitted, the cmdlet will attempt to use the last session created in this PowerShell session.

Type: Object
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 0
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Username
docs.text:
The username of the account to modify. This value is required.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: CommonParameters
docs.text: This cmdlet supports the common parameters: -Debug, -ErrorAction, -ErrorVariable, -InformationAction, -InformationVariable, -OutVariable, -OutBuffer, -PipelineVariable, -Verbose, -WarningAction, and -WarningVariable. For more information, see about_CommonParameters.

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text: This cmdlet performs account management operations on the Frigate server and typically requires administrative privileges. Passwords should be provided as SecureString values to avoid exposing secrets in logs or console history.

docs.title: SHORT DESCRIPTION
docs.text: PowerShell module for administering and querying Frigate NVRs.

docs.title: LONG DESCRIPTION
docs.text:
This module provides a set of PowerShell cmdlets to authenticate to, query, and manage Frigate servers via their HTTP API. It is intended for technical types like system administrators who need to inspect configuration, list events, manage users, or perform administrative actions such as restarting a Frigate instance.

Commands are simple wrappers around Frigate API endpoints and return PowerShell objects suitable for inspection, filtering, or export. Use New-FrigateSession to authenticate, then run subsequent commands against that session.

docs.title: Optional Subtopics
docs.text:
Common tasks:

  • Inspecting server configuration (Get-FrigateConfig).
  • Listing recent events (Get-FrigateEvent, Get-FrigateReview).
  • Managing users (Get-FrigateUsers, New-FrigateUser, Set-FrigateUser, Remove-FrigateUser).

docs.title: EXAMPLES
docs.text:
Create an authenticated session and list users:

$cred = Get-Credential -Message 'Frigate admin credentials'
New-FrigateSession -Uri 'https://frigate.example.local' -Credential $cred
Get-FrigateUsers

This creates a session and displays configured users.

docs.title: NOTE
docs.text: Commands that modify server state (creating users, restarting the server, changing passwords) require appropriate administrative privileges. Actions may interrupt recording or streaming.

docs.title: TROUBLESHOOTING NOTE
docs.text: If an operation fails with an authentication error, verify credentials and that the Frigate server is reachable from the machine running the cmdlets. For network problems, confirm the server URI and any firewall or proxy settings.

docs.title: KEYWORDS
docs.text:
• frigate
  • video analytics
  • surveillance
  • NVR
  • VMS
  • CCTV
